title: So I'm playing the new Riven skin because its beautiful but..
body:
Im still learning Riven.

I know i am not good, i have I just got tier 4 mastery, and thats kinda cool.

Im vsing another Riven with 500k mastery.

You do not need to:

-Flame me when she out plays me
-Flame me when i get ganked and you have no provided any support or suggestions
- Flame me for messing up a combo (because i use mages, and riven is a whole different play style for me)
- Tell me to kill myself because I'm learning
- Become overly toxic in a normal


TL;DR
Its a normal, people play them to learn and have fun. Telling people to kill themselves because they want to try a new champion is just unreal.

My main mission though is more around business technology strategy for Talent and supporting our key systems that keep the lights on - stuff like your HRIS, Payroll, Comp, and so on. I also work with our infrastructure engineers to explain what data we have, the process in place and how that gets surfaced through API's and consumed by our other internal intranet applications. 

It's pretty cool because it's a pretty young company with a LOT of talented people who are building the unique, quality of life applications that help make Riot an awesome place to work.

In theory, I'm the person that is replacing the manual tasks with technology. My best suggestion in these times is to be the person who knows and empathizes with the work so you know how to be a solutions architect (which is probably the closest title I can think of as to what I actually do). I translate functional and technical need into an actionable plan with our systems team, and then help deliver the solutions and support it as need arises.

One could argue that that is a typical IT Engineer's responsibilities, and you'd be absolutely right. Talent systems solutions vary from company to company - sometimes it falls under IT and sometimes it falls under HR/Talent. I make the argument that having it fall under Talent sets the team up for success much better, since you are working directly with your customers - those that are using your solutions and the best points for your feedback loop. The closer you are to the problems, the better you'll be able to design solutions for them.

During development a lot of the team working on the Riven skin also picked her up and tried to learn her in order to do the skin justice and really understand what's important. It was a long hard road and we lost many good people along the way...

I remember in particular the character artist for Riven, who dutifully laned against the pre-alpha Camille build which was suuuuper op.
You wouldn't happen to have any juicy details on the alpha Camille, would you?

My team was working on the launch skin - our testing was for bugs and clipping etc, although if you're lucky one of the champ team might come out of the woodwork. There was some interesting exploration around what gadgets she would use and the balance between human and machine.

I have level 7 and around 236k mastery on Riven and I still get flamed from time to time like "Boosted to lvl 7?" and "You're lvl 7, you should be better" etc. 


This is probably why Riven mains are known for being toxic; because everyone else treats them like shit and are assholes whenever they see one, so the Riven tilts and flames.
I got mastery 6 heimer but i dont play him that often anymore. I played him recently and did kinda bad and got flamed for it. I think people assume that lv 7 mastery champs would go 10-0
124k mastery thresh but i still miss one or two hooks sometimes. The moment I miss one, The missing pings start spamming like crazy. And if I hit a madlife hook, nobody notices
Because it's easier to notice mistakes than good plays. Rare is the occasion when a team mate praises your good plays.

If there is anything I learned in the years I've been playing League, its that due to the unreasonable hate Yasuo, Riven, Lee, Vayne and whoever else gets on a daily basis, those mains typically end up either massively toxic right back or unapologetically thick skinned.

Don't let it bother you that much. They'll give you shit no matter what you do, so try to fall into the thick skinned side of things.

I'd tell you to go to normal draft instead of blind pick, to avoid mirror lanes in the future but, 10 bans mean you'll probably never get Riven anyway.

actually, riven isn't banned hell of a lot like yasuo is. i've played her at least 20 times today

I would like to suggest watching boxbox on Twitch. He is a Riven main in high divisions (Diamond or so). He's very friendly and you can watch him to learn some moves. He also messes up time to time on his Riven plays, Riot Fenyx says.

If you truly want to get good at riven, don't give up at all. People do this shit all the time to people, regardless of how experienced they are. 

Just don't straight up int if you don't know what you're doing. I faced a Riven last game who decided it was a good idea to go full lethality into a rammus top and had like 15ish deaths. Don't be like that guy.
If you are learning a new champ just mute all at the beginning of the game so you don't have to deal with the flamers. Then when you are decent at the champ you can play with everyone unmuted.

Or just mute all as a general rule for all matches, esp ones that might tilt you (losing match ups for the majority of the map, bad late game, poor communication from the others in champ select, etc).
